article.headline: Xavier 62, Richmond 51
article.story: RICHMOND, Va. (AP) -- Xavier had been there before against Richmond. Little more than two weeks ago, the Musketeers led the Spiders with about 10 minutes to play, then faded on its home court and lost, 53-44. The Musketeers turned the tables Tuesday night, holding onto a 7-point lead down the stretch and beating Richmond 62-51 at the Robins Center. "Our three seniors stepped up and did a great job," Musketeers coach Thad Matta said. "I told the team with 10 minutes to go, `We're right in the exact same situation we were in 15 days ago or whatever it was." This time, "I thought our defense really prevailed down the stretch." Lionel Chalmers scored 20 points, including a huge 3-pointer with 2:40 remaining, and Romain Sato had all 14 of his in the second half, including another dagger 3-pointer with 1:58 left that ended Richmond's chances. The victory was the third straight for Xavier at Richmond, and for the second straight season avenged a rare Xavier home loss to the Spiders. Sato, who was rushing his shots and trying too hard to find them, was encourgaed by Matta at halftime to slow down and stop trying too hard. "He let the game come to him and hit some big shots," Matta said. Richmond (13-10, 5-5) lost for only the second time in seven games and went more than 5{ minutes without a field goal late in the second half, allowing Xavier to creep its lead to 54-44 with 4:13 remaining. After two free throws pulled Richmond to within 54-46 with 3:06 to play, Chalmers swished a 3-pointer -- his fourth -- from the right corner. Gaston Moliva's three-point play ended the Spiders' field goal drought with 2:19 left, but then it was Sato's turn from way out on the left side. Anthony Myles added 13 points for Xavier, and Sato had 11 rebounds. The Musketeers won their third straight after losing five of six. The Spiders were just 8-for-31 from the field in the second half, and scoring leader Mike Skrocki had all 21 of his points in the first 28 minutes. He missed his last seven shots and was 2-for-12 on 3-pointers. Coach Jerry Wainwright said he wasn't making excuses, but he thought his team looked tired, especially late when many shots came up short. "We just seemed drained," Wainwright said, "unlike our team all year. We usually have someone that jumps out and gives us a spark. We kind of build around that guy, but we couldn't find that spark tonight." Gaston Moliva came the closest with 11 points and eight rebounds. The Musketeers' surprising zone defense worked, Skrocki said, forcing the Spiders to take a lot of outside shots -- they tried 25 3-pointers. "We had open looks," Skrocki said. "If we knocked them down, they have to come out and play man and it's a whole new game."
